name: Australian TV in the 1990s
description: In the 1990s, Australians and Australian culture was changing: so too were the representations of it on television.

key_work.title: 1990s Australian TV miniature
key_work.credit_line: Designed by Graham McGuffie, Emily Boutard and Megafun
key_work.brief_description: This gorgeous miniature TV model celebrates the evolving living rooms of Australians and beloved TV from the 1990s.

constellations_primary.name: Australian TV in the 1990s
constellations_primary.description: In the 1990s, Australians and Australian culture was changing: so too were the representations of it on television.

start.title: Heartbreak High
start.brief_description: Heartbreak High is a popular Australian TV series that dealt with the students at a tough high school in a multi-racial area of Sydney, and proved to be a more gritty and fast-paced show than many of its contemporaries.

constellations_other.name: Teenage dreams
constellations_other.description: Puberty Blues realistically represents the trials and tribulations of Australian adolescence. Since then a diverse range of originals and remakes offer new perspectives on teen dreams.

constellations_other.name: Australian TV in the 1990s
constellations_other.description: In the 1990s, Australians and Australian culture was changing: so too were the representations of it on television.

end.title: The Heartbreak Kid
end.brief_description: Christina (Claudia Karvan) is a school teacher from a wealthy Greek Australian background, engaged to a lawyer and content with the course of her life until she begins at Hartley High and meets aspiring soccer player, 17-year-old Nick (Alex Dimitriades)…

constellations_other.name: Australian TV in the 1990s
constellations_other.description: In the 1990s, Australians and Australian culture was changing: so too were the representations of it on television.

links.description: Heartbreak High was unusual for Australian programming at the time as it was a teen-targeted show - performed by mostly teen actors - that tackled racism, homophobia, youth homelessness, sexuality and more. It was a spin-off of The Heartbreak Kid.

start.title: 1990s Australian TV miniature
start.credit_line: Designed by Graham McGuffie, Emily Boutard and Megafun
start.brief_description: This gorgeous miniature TV model celebrates the evolving living rooms of Australians and beloved TV from the 1990s.

constellations_primary.name: Australian TV in the 1990s
constellations_primary.description: In the 1990s, Australians and Australian culture was changing: so too were the representations of it on television.

end.title: Johnson & Friends
end.creator_credit: Ian Munro and John D. Patterson
end.brief_description: Johnson and Friends is one of the most beloved Australian kids shows, airing on the ABC in the perfect timeslot between school and dinner. It featured toys that came to life and starred ACMI CEO Katrina Sedgwick as McDuff.

constellations_other.name: Flipping through the evolution of animation
constellations_other.description: Animation has come a long way since flip books were popular. These optical toys gave the illusion of movement, but now whole films and special effects are animated entirely through computers.

constellations_other.name: Australian TV in the 1990s
constellations_other.description: In the 1990s, Australians and Australian culture was changing: so too were the representations of it on television.

recommendations.quote: Before Katrina Sedgwick landed the lead role at ACMI, she starred in a range of iconic TV shows and movies, including The Last Wave (1977) and E Street (1989). But our favourite role of Katrina's is the cheeky concertina McDuff in Johnson and Friends (1990â€“95).

links.description: Children’s programming shifted in the 90s, with shows like Johnson & Friends kickstarting the decade with a premise like Toy Story: toys that come alive once their human owner isn’t around, brought to life in the show by puppets.

start.title: The Heartbreak Kid
start.brief_description: Christina (Claudia Karvan) is a school teacher from a wealthy Greek Australian background, engaged to a lawyer and content with the course of her life until she begins at Hartley High and meets aspiring soccer player, 17-year-old Nick (Alex Dimitriades)…

constellations_other.name: Australian TV in the 1990s
constellations_other.description: In the 1990s, Australians and Australian culture was changing: so too were the representations of it on television.

end.title: Blue Heelers
end.brief_description: Blue Heelers is an Australian police drama series which depicted the lives of police officers stationed at the fictional Mount Thomas police station in a small town in Victoria.

constellations_other.name: Suburban scenes
constellations_other.description: Lisa McCune is best known for her role as Constable Maggie Doyle in the television series Blue Heelers (1994â€“2006). In addition to showing the day-to-day lives of police in a small Victorian town, the series explores the various dynamics of suburbiaâ€”a theme present throughout the whole of screen media.

constellations_other.name: Australian TV in the 1990s
constellations_other.description: In the 1990s, Australians and Australian culture was changing: so too were the representations of it on television.

links.description: Alex Dimitriades played Nick in both the film and TV spin-off. Nick Lathouris, Doris Younane and Scott Major also appeared in both the film and TV series, and William McInnes starred as Southgate in the movie before going on to find fame in Blue Heelers.

start.title: All Saints
start.brief_description: All Saints is an Australian medical drama that first screened on the Seven Network. It was one of Australia’s highest rating dramas and also achieved popularity overseas in many countries.

constellations_other.name: Australian TV in the 1990s
constellations_other.description: In the 1990s, Australians and Australian culture was changing: so too were the representations of it on television.

end.title: Full Frontal
end.brief_description: Full Frontal was an Australian sketch comedy series which debuted in 1993. The show first aired on the Seven Network on 13 May 1993, and finished on 18 September 1997.

constellations_other.name: Eric Bana
constellations_other.description: There must be something that draws Australian creatives like Eric Bana to darker material as they shoot to stardom overseas. Australia's penal colony past perhaps?

constellations_other.name: Nightly news and laughs
constellations_other.description: Throughout the decades on Australian screens, comedy and news have often gone hand-in-hand.

constellations_other.name: Australian TV in the 1990s
constellations_other.description: In the 1990s, Australians and Australian culture was changing: so too were the representations of it on television.

links.description: All Saints was the Australian answer to ER as it focused on the Ward 17 staff at All Saints hospital. Although he was better known for comedic roles, Eric Bana made one of his first appearances on the show.

start.title: Blinky Bill
start.brief_description: The film tells the story of Blinky Billâ€™s childhood with his animal friends in the Australian bush.

constellations_other.name: Australian TV in the 1990s
constellations_other.description: In the 1990s, Australians and Australian culture was changing: so too were the representations of it on television.

end.title: The Ferals [Puppets]
end.credit_line:
Designed by Garth Frost

Puppet maker Tina Matthews

Australia, 1993

Courtesy of Emma de Vries

Edie Kurzer, Australia, 2020
end.brief_description: “They discovered fame and fortune and they’re never going back.” Or so proclaimed the catchy hook of The Ferals TV theme song. This kids’ program debuted on ABC TV in 1994 and then, after two successful seasons, it has endured in Australian pop culture. Capitalising on the grunge aesthetic of the time, it followed an unruly bunch of feral animals living in a share house with flatmates played by human actors. The ditzy rabbit Mixy and sassy cat Modigliana were key members of the show, adding to the tradition of children’s programming featuring puppets in starring roles, including Lift Off (1992-95) and Mr Squiggle (1959-99).

constellations_other.name: Australian TV in the 1990s
constellations_other.description: In the 1990s, Australians and Australian culture was changing: so too were the representations of it on television.

links.description: While Blinky Bill was the cuddly kind of marsupial, the animals in The Ferals are anything but. These edgy, punk-rock rodents and cats still managed to strike a chord with audiences and were beloved by kids in the 1990s.

start.brief_description: Johnson and Friends is one of the most beloved Australian kids shows, airing on the ABC in the perfect timeslot between school and dinner. It featured toys that came to life and starred ACMI CEO Katrina Sedgwick as McDuff.

end.title: Blinky Bill
end.brief_description: The film tells the story of Blinky Billâ€™s childhood with his animal friends in the Australian bush.

constellations_other.name: Australian TV in the 1990s
constellations_other.description: In the 1990s, Australians and Australian culture was changing: so too were the representations of it on television.

links.description: Johnson & Friends was a big hit for ABC and was syndicated globally, with additional episodes commissioned for the US. The ABC also greenlit The Adventures Of Blinky Bill a few years later, based on the books by author Dorothy Wall.

end.title: Heartbreak High
end.brief_description: Heartbreak High is a popular Australian TV series that dealt with the students at a tough high school in a multi-racial area of Sydney, and proved to be a more gritty and fast-paced show than many of its contemporaries.

constellations_other.name: Teenage dreams
constellations_other.description: Puberty Blues realistically represents the trials and tribulations of Australian adolescence. Since then a diverse range of originals and remakes offer new perspectives on teen dreams.

constellations_other.name: Australian TV in the 1990s
constellations_other.description: In the 1990s, Australians and Australian culture was changing: so too were the representations of it on television.

links.description: The first season of Blinky Bill featured a strong environmental message, just like animated feature FernGully, which was released around the same time. Environmentalism also featured in teen drama series Heartbreak High as students protested global warming.

In addition to showing the day-to-day lives of police in a small Victorian town, the series explores the various dynamics of suburbiaâ€”a theme present throughout the whole of screen media.

end.title: All Saints
end.brief_description: All Saints is an Australian medical drama that first screened on the Seven Network. It was one of Australia’s highest rating dramas and also achieved popularity overseas in many countries.

constellations_other.name: Australian TV in the 1990s
constellations_other.description: In the 1990s, Australians and Australian culture was changing: so too were the representations of it on television.

links.description: Blue Heelers is one of Australia’s most successful police procedurals and the equally most-awarded show in Logie history. It set up a formula of following the lives of emergency professionals that shows like All Saints followed.
